desc.size: Shrub, 3.5 - 4.5 m tall, 3.5 - 4.5 m wide. Stout with irregularly spreading branches.

part.partText: green and minutely hairy when young, becoming gray and hairless with age.

opposite, short-stalked, dark green, 2.5 - 6 cm long, 0.5 - 1.5 cm wide, oblong egg-shaped to lance-shaped, tip rounded to pointed, margins non-toothed, glossy, smooth. Leaves turning purplish in autumn.

have both male and female reproductive organs (perfect); on short axillary branches; borne in a dense, terminal, branched inflorescence; white, small, tubular, petals 4, unpleasant odor. The flower tube is equal to or shorter than the lobes.
a berry-like drupe; in clusters on short axillary branches; lustrous black, 8.5 mm long, spherical.

similarSpecies.comments: Without flowers, this species can be difficult to distinguish from Ligustrum obtusifolium. The flower tube is equal to or shorter than the lobes; on L. obtusifolium the flower tube is 2 - 3 times as long as the lobes. In general, L. obtusifolium has more blunt-tipped and oblong, nearly stalkless, leaves than L. vulgare.

speciesPage.habitatEcology: Occasional in woods, where birds are responsible for its dispersal. Other habitats include vacant lots, old fields, dunes, and along fences. Also found along rivers and other moist sites.

notes.comments: Introduced from Europe and cultivated in the Chicago Region. Anthracnose twig blight (Glomerella cingulata) is serious on this species.

etymology.comments: Ligustrum is the Latin word for privet. Vulgare means common.
